item.title: hello-elementor
item.dc:creator: jbarkle1

item.title: Community Drop-In Meditation
item.dc:creator: jbarkle1
item.content:encoded: These are difficult times. So let's come together and practice some stress reduction and learn some adaptive coping skills. As counterintuitive as it may seem, paying attention to the thoughts, emotions and body sensations that are arising in these scary times may actually help us manage our stress. We can be blindsided by our fears when we constantly push them away. Mindfulness practice is about paying attention to the present moment, whether we like it or not. Mindfulness doesn't change the difficult times, it gives the deep roots we need to weather the storm.

item.title: 6 week Unwinding Anxiety
item.dc:creator: jbarkle1
item.content:encoded:
A new, evidenced - based therapeutic intervention using a combination of a digital app on a cell phone or other device, in conjunction with weekly live class meetings with a trained program facilitator/counselor and offers 24/7 support on the spot, when you need it most.
This program, developed by Judson Brewer, MD PHD, Director of Research and Innovation at Brown University Center for Mindfulness School of Public Health is a ground- breaking, evidence-based method of habit change which engages the brain’s inherent, reward -based learning system. When anxiety strikes, triggering urges to react in ways that are unhealthy, whether it is to overeat, abuse substances, give in to anger or other impulses, we are usually feeling alone to battle the anxiety, overcome the urge and “white knuckle” the situation on our own.
With one on one guidance, as well as group support, we identify the triggers and behaviors and learn to short circuit the habit loop before anxiety takes over. In accordance with the latest neuroscience, change is not dependent on harsh self -discipline, but rather enlists the brain as an ally in moving toward behaviors that are intrinsically healthy and rewarding.

item.title: Book Study Course: The Miracle of Mindfulness
item.dc:creator: jbarkle1
item.content:encoded: Thich Nhat Hanh said, “mindfulness is the capacity to be here, to witness deeply everything that happens in the present moment.” This course is about learning to apply mindfulness to our everyday lives through the teachings in The Miracle of Mindfulness. We will practice together, sit together, and reflect on and embrace the changes mindfulness can bring. The class will meet every Thursday for 1.5 hours a week for 6 weeks. Book: The Miracle of Mindfulness by Thich Nhat Hanh -Participants purchase their own book -Electronic versions of this book may be available for free online Vanessa Miller-Curtis, Ph.D. has over 12 years of experience in a variety of settings. Vanessa has spent several years developing and leading educational programs in the areas of Mindfulness, Shame and Guilt, and Contemplative Psychology in prison settings, outpatient clinics, and brain injury recovery and support groups. The effectiveness of therapeutic and educational programming for anyone on their overall well-being and its use as a tool to address anger, anxiety and other mental health issues is at the core of this work. Therapeutic educational programs pertain to psychological health and well-being. The importance of therapeutic and educational programming for any human being cannot adequately be expressed. For some, this may be the first opportunity to address a lifetime of maladaptive behaviors.

item.title: Privacy Policy
item.dc:creator: jbarkle1
item.content:encoded:
Who we are

Suggested text: Our website address is: http://localhost/finalproject.

Comments

Suggested text: When visitors leave comments on the site we collect the data shown in the comments form, and also the visitor’s IP address and browser user agent string to help spam detection.

An anonymized string created from your email address (also called a hash) may be provided to the Gravatar service to see if you are using it. The Gravatar service privacy policy is available here: https://automattic.com/privacy/. After approval of your comment, your profile picture is visible to the public in the context of your comment.

Media

Suggested text: If you upload images to the website, you should avoid uploading images with embedded location data (EXIF GPS) included. Visitors to the website can download and extract any location data from images on the website.

Cookies

Suggested text: If you leave a comment on our site you may opt-in to saving your name, email address and website in cookies. These are for your convenience so that you do not have to fill in your details again when you leave another comment. These cookies will last for one year.

If you visit our login page, we will set a temporary cookie to determine if your browser accepts cookies. This cookie contains no personal data and is discarded when you close your browser.

When you log in, we will also set up several cookies to save your login information and your screen display choices. Login cookies last for two days, and screen options cookies last for a year. If you select "Remember Me", your login will persist for two weeks. If you log out of your account, the login cookies will be removed.

If you edit or publish an article, an additional cookie will be saved in your browser. This cookie includes no personal data and simply indicates the post ID of the article you just edited. It expires after 1 day.

Embedded content from other websites

Suggested text: Articles on this site may include embedded content (e.g. videos, images, articles, etc.). Embedded content from other websites behaves in the exact same way as if the visitor has visited the other website.

These websites may collect data about you, use cookies, embed additional third-party tracking, and monitor your interaction with that embedded content, including tracking your interaction with the embedded content if you have an account and are logged in to that website.

Who we share your data with

Suggested text: If you request a password reset, your IP address will be included in the reset email.

How long we retain your data

Suggested text: If you leave a comment, the comment and its metadata are retained indefinitely. This is so we can recognize and approve any follow-up comments automatically instead of holding them in a moderation queue.

For users that register on our website (if any), we also store the personal information they provide in their user profile. All users can see, edit, or delete their personal information at any time (except they cannot change their username). Website administrators can also see and edit that information.

What rights you have over your data

Suggested text: If you have an account on this site, or have left comments, you can request to receive an exported file of the personal data we hold about you, including any data you have provided to us. You can also request that we erase any personal data we hold about you. This does not include any data we are obliged to keep for administrative, legal, or security purposes.

Where we send your data

Suggested text: Visitor comments may be checked through an automated spam detection service.

item.title: Our Team
item.dc:creator: jbarkle1
item.content:encoded:
Mary Beth Stern, Certified MBSR Teacher

Mary Beth Stern is a Mindfulness-Based Stress Reduction (MBSR) teacher, trained and certified by the Center for Mindfulness at UMASS Medical School. She is a Florida Board Certified Addictions counselor, and a qualified facilitator in the app-based Habit Change Programs including Eat Right Now and Unwinding Anxiety, developed by Judson Brewer, MD. She continues advanced mindfulness training at the Center for Mindfulness at Brown University. 

She is Level 2 MBITAC ( Mindfulness- Based Intervention Teacher Assessment Criteria) trained and actively participates in several peer mentoring groups. 

Since 2014, she has taught throughout south Florida, offering mindfulness training at hospitals, behavioral health facilities and substance abuse treatment centers. She is currently a senior teacher for Mindful Leader, offering MBSR online and individual mindfulness coaching to an international global population.​

Dr. Vanessa Miller-Curtis

Vanessa Miller-Curtis, Ph.D. has over 12 years of experience in a variety of settings. Vanessa has spent several years developing and leading educational programs in the areas of Mindfulness, Shame and Guilt, and Contemplative Psychology in prison settings, outpatient clinics, and brain injury recovery and support groups.

The effectiveness of therapeutic and educational programming for anyone on their overall well-being and its use as a tool to address anger, anxiety and other mental health issues is at the core of this work. Therapeutic educational programs pertain to psychological health and well-being. The importance of therapeutic and educational programming for any human being cannot adequately be expressed. For some, this may be the first opportunity to address a lifetime of maladaptive behaviors. The changes in thoughts, emotions, and behavior as a result of continued exposure to therapeutic and educational programming often creates an intangible shift in attitudes and values.

Vanessa has a strong daily Mindfulness and MBSR personal practice. She says, "engaging in Mindfulness and MBSR daily has helped shift my perspective and provide a balance in life like no other program has been able to do." Vanessa holds a Ph.D. in Cognitive Psychology from the University of California, Riverside and a Master’s degree in Clinical Psychology from Chapman University.

Leila Nabors, Certified MBSR Teacher, Co-Founder

Leila Nabors, M.Ed., LPC has been in private practice as a psychotherapist for over 18 years. She has over 25 years of experience as a counselor in private practice, community mental health and public schools.  In private practice Leila became interested in Mindfulness-Based Interventions (MBI) as a therapeutic approach and Mindfulness-Based Stress Reduction (MBSR) as a psychoeducational program to enhance healing and increase well-being.

Mindfulness-Based Stress Reduction is a  program that uses mindfulness and meditation to help people cope more effectively with stress and illness by increasing present moment awareness.   Leila has studied with Dr. Jon Kabat-Zinn who developed Mindfulness-Based Stress Reduction (MBSR) in the late 1970’s at the University of Massachusetts Medical School.  After six years of training and practice, she received certification as a Mindfulness-Based Stress Reduction teacher.  

Leila is the only certified teacher in the state of Alabama and one of only a handful in the Southeast. She and Beth Cook founded the Alabama Institute for Mindfulness in 2015. 

Beth Cook, LPC, Co-Founder

Beth Cook, MS, LPC, is a psychotherapist with 30 years of experience in a variety of settings including community mental health centers, public schools, inpatient psychiatric facilities and, since 2005, private practice. In addition to a foundation in Cognitive Behavioral Therapy she has trained extensively in the areas of spiritually-oriented and mind/body therapeutic models. Throughout her career, Beth has been interested in the intersection of emotional, physical and spiritual aspects of health and wholeness and she now integrates mindfulness practice into the psychotherapeutic interventions she uses with clients.

Beth has completed the 8-week Mindfulness-Based Stress Reduction class and maintains a regular meditation practice. She is also a certified spiritual director who honors the wisdom found in all of the world’s enduring spiritual and religious traditions.

Beth is a core faculty member of the Metagem Institute which offers training in spiritual direction and the contemplative path. In this role she teaches mindfulness as an integrative practice – one which contributes to the practitioner’s own self-knowledge and well-being. Beth and Leila founded the Alabama Institute for Mindfulness in 2015.

item.title: What is Mindfulness?
item.dc:creator: jbarkle1
item.content:encoded:
What is Mindfulness?

It is interesting that many articles that try to define mindfulness begin with the word "simply." Phrases such as "simply" or "simply put mindfulness is…” are an effort to concisely express a concept, mindfulness, that has become increasingly difficult to relate to in our fast-paced stressed-out culture. Dr. Jon Kabat-Zinn defines mindfulness as the awarenesss that arises when you “pay attention, in a particular way: on purpose, in the present moment, and non-judgementally”.  When we talk about mindfulnesss, we mean beginning to really notice sensations in the body, thoughts and emotions coming and going, and fully taking in our experience, whatever it is, with all of our senses. This is what is meant by “paying attention, in a particular way: on purpose."  

While the concept of mindfulness may be quite simple, it may not be that easy to bring the practice of mindfulness to our daily living.  So the invitation here is to begin to reengage with your life fully, by paying attention on purpose, getting off automatic pilot and opening to whatever is present in this moment. Mindfulness helps us respond to our life circumstances, whatever they are, rather than automatically reacting from the old familiar habitual patterns. And yes, that means paying attention to the difficulties we encounter too. By attending to those difficulties in this way, we may begin to see through a new lens and discover new possibilities. The difficulties probably won’t disappear, but our relationship to those difficulties may be transformed. 

Practicing mindfulness might mean meditating, sitting in the yard and paying attention “on purpose” to the sights and sounds of nature, or it might be pausing for three or four breaths many times during the day. The following explanation of mindfulness by Sharon Salzberg emphasizes that mindfulnesss is not just a concept to be understood but a practice, or more precisely a way of being.

https://youtu.be/p33800Pu2P8 Signup For Newsletter

It is interesting that many articles that try to define mindfulness begin with the word \"simply.\" Phrases such as \"simply\" or \"simply put mindfulness is\u2026\u201d are an effort to concisely express a concept, mindfulness, that has become increasingly difficult to relate to in our fast-paced stressed-out culture. Dr. Jon Kabat-Zinn defines mindfulness as the awarenesss that arises when you \u201cpay attention, in a particular way: on purpose, in the present moment, and non-judgementally\u201d.\u00a0\u00a0When we talk about mindfulnesss, we mean beginning to really notice sensations in the body, thoughts and emotions coming and going, and fully taking in our experience, whatever it is, with\u00a0all\u00a0<\/em><\/strong>of our senses. This is what is meant by \u201cpaying attention, in a particular way: on purpose.\" \u00a0

While the concept of mindfulness may be quite\u00a0simple<\/em>, it may not be that\u00a0easy<\/em>\u00a0to bring the practice of mindfulness to our daily living. \u00a0So the invitation here is to begin to reengage with your life fully, by paying attention on purpose, getting off automatic pilot and opening to whatever is present in\u00a0this<\/em><\/strong>\u00a0moment. Mindfulness helps us respond to our life circumstances, whatever they are, rather than automatically reacting from the old familiar habitual patterns. And yes, that means paying attention to the difficulties we encounter too. By attending to those difficulties in this way, we may begin to see through a new lens and discover new possibilities. The difficulties probably won\u2019t disappear, but our relationship to those difficulties may be transformed.\u00a0

Practicing mindfulness might mean meditating, sitting in the yard and paying attention \u201con purpose\u201d to the sights and sounds of nature, or it might be pausing for three or four breaths many times during the day. The following explanation of mindfulness by Sharon Salzberg emphasizes that mindfulnesss is not just a concept to be understood but a practice, or more precisely a way of\u00a0being.<\/em><\/strong><\/p>"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"text-editor"}],"isInner":false}],"isInner":false},{"id":"227c573","elType":"section","settings":[],"elements":[{"id":"0e25773","elType":"column","settings":{"_column_size":100,"_inline_size":null},"elements":[{"id":"139b727","elType":"widget","settings":{"youtube_url":"https:\/\/youtu.be\/p33800Pu2P8","vimeo_url":"https:\/\/vimeo.com\/235215203","dailymotion_url":"https:\/\/www.dailymotion.com\/video\/x6tqhqb"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"video"}],"isInner":false}],"isInner":false},{"id":"d52b041","elType":"section","settings":[],"elements":[{"id":"536a03d","elType":"column","settings":{"_column_size":100,"_inline_size":null},"elements":[{"id":"cd54269","elType":"widget","settings":[],"elements":[],"widgetType":"spacer"}],"isInner":false}],"isInner":false},{"id":"b4fe045","elType":"section","settings":[],"elements":[{"id":"47d5bfe","elType":"column","settings":{"_column_size":100,"_inline_size":null},"elements":[{"id":"3d0d1b9","elType":"widget","settings":{"text":"Signup For Newsletter","link":{"url":"https:\/\/visitor.r20.constantcontact.com\/d.jsp?llr=hi9yq7vab&p=oi&m=1123017320711&sit=w4ugdpfkb&f=3eed87df-893a-418f-8a4d-f93dc2efa5b4","is_external":"","nofollow":"","custom_attributes":""},"align":"center","background_color":"#C86565"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"button"}],"isInner":false}],"isInner":false},{"id":"41e32b7","elType":"section","settings":[],"elements":[{"id":"2a9d1cf","elType":"column","settings":{"_column_size":100,"_inline_size":null},"elements":[{"id":"e600851","elType":"widget","settings":[],"elements":[],"widgetType":"spacer"}],"isInner":false}],"isInner":false}]

Registration

Please take care when selecting the class you would like to attend. There are different class options for the year so note the dates and time of day your class is offered before you put it in your "cart". 

Unwinding Anxiety

$225.00 

ONLINE VIA ZOOM CLASS RUNS 6 WEEKS BEGINNING Tuesday, April 12 through Tuesday, May 17, 2022 From 4:30pm to 6:00pm CST (5:30pm to 7:00pm EST)     

TUITION  $225

APP COST  $115 (purchased separately online, info supplied after registration)

TOTAL COST $340 or $225 (if you already have the app)

Add To Cart

The Miracle of Mindfulness: A Book Study Course

$195.00 

Thursday, April 21 through Thursday, May 26, 2022

Time: 11:30am to 1:00pm (CST)

The class will meet every Thursday for 1.5 hours a week for 6 weeks. 

Add To Cart

Mindfulness-Based Stress Reduction(MBSR) Class - Tuesday Evenings Sept - Nov 2022

$395.00 

8 Week Stress Reduction Program 

Tuesday evenings September 20,2022 - November 8, 2022 from 5:30pm - 8:00pm

Required Orientation on Tuesday, September 13, 2022 from 5:30pm-8:00pm

Add To Cart

Tuition assistance my be available to those that qualify.

More Info

item.content:encoded:
The mission of the Alabama Institute for Mindfulness (AIM) is to promote mindfulness to a public struggling with the impact of stress on wellness and daily living by helping individuals access their inner resources and cultivate resilience, health, and a sense of well-being.
Learn More

item.title: Refund and Returns Policy
item.dc:creator: jbarkle1
item.content:encoded:
This is a sample page.

Overview

Our refund and returns policy lasts 30 days. If 30 days have passed since your purchase, we can’t offer you a full refund or exchange.

To be eligible for a return, your item must be unused and in the same condition that you received it. It must also be in the original packaging.

Several types of goods are exempt from being returned. Perishable goods such as food, flowers, newspapers or magazines cannot be returned. We also do not accept products that are intimate or sanitary goods, hazardous materials, or flammable liquids or gases.

Additional non-returnable items:

  • Gift cards
  • Downloadable software products
  • Some health and personal care items

To complete your return, we require a receipt or proof of purchase.

Please do not send your purchase back to the manufacturer.

There are certain situations where only partial refunds are granted:

  • Book with obvious signs of use
  • CD, DVD, VHS tape, software, video game, cassette tape, or vinyl record that has been opened.
  • Any item not in its original condition, is damaged or missing parts for reasons not due to our error.
  • Any item that is returned more than 30 days after delivery

Refunds

Once your return is received and inspected, we will send you an email to notify you that we have received your returned item. We will also notify you of the approval or rejection of your refund.

If you are approved, then your refund will be processed, and a credit will automatically be applied to your credit card or original method of payment, within a certain amount of days.

Late or missing refunds

If you haven’t received a refund yet, first check your bank account again.

Then contact your credit card company, it may take some time before your refund is officially posted.

Next contact your bank. There is often some processing time before a refund is posted.

If you’ve done all of this and you still have not received your refund yet, please contact us at {email address}.

Sale items

Only regular priced items may be refunded. Sale items cannot be refunded.

Exchanges

We only replace items if they are defective or damaged. If you need to exchange it for the same item, send us an email at {email address} and send your item to: {physical address}.

Gifts

If the item was marked as a gift when purchased and shipped directly to you, you’ll receive a gift credit for the value of your return. Once the returned item is received, a gift certificate will be mailed to you.

If the item wasn’t marked as a gift when purchased, or the gift giver had the order shipped to themselves to give to you later, we will send a refund to the gift giver and they will find out about your return.

Shipping returns

To return your product, you should mail your product to: {physical address}.

You will be responsible for paying for your own shipping costs for returning your item. Shipping costs are non-refundable. If you receive a refund, the cost of return shipping will be deducted from your refund.

Depending on where you live, the time it may take for your exchanged product to reach you may vary.

If you are returning more expensive items, you may consider using a trackable shipping service or purchasing shipping insurance. We don’t guarantee that we will receive your returned item.

Need help?

Contact us at {email} for questions related to refunds and returns.

item.title: MBSR
item.dc:creator: jbarkle1
item.content:encoded:
What is Mindfulness-Based Stress Reduction (MBSR)?
 
Mindfulness-Based Stress Reduction (MBSR) is an eight-week intensive, psychoeducational program which was launched in 1979 at the University of Massachusetts Medical Center by Dr. Jon Kabat-Zinn. More than 20,000 people have completed this evidence-based program and learned to cultivate inner resources and develop skills that help them cope more effectively with stress, pain and illness. MBSR offers participants a powerful integrative approach, that when applied to everyday living can lead to health, healing and well-being.  Mindfulness is about getting off "auto pilot," waking up and being fully present in the richness of each moment of life. Present moment awareness creates a space which helps us consciously respond to life  rather than reacting automatically from habit. The MBSR program utilizes meditation and mindful movement to to help individuals cultivate skills, increase awareness and access innate inner resources. Mindfulness helps us develop a deep inner reservoir accessible during the inevitable stressful events encountered in life. 
 
According to Jon Kabat-Zinn mindfulness is "paying attention in a particular way; on purpose, in the present moment, and nonjudgmentally." It is not about "clearing" or "quieting" the mind but it is about purposefully paying attention and bringing awareness to sensations in the body, thoughts, emotions and even the environment around you. In an MBSR class you might be asked to "sit" and notice your breath, physical sensations , sounds, thoughts or emotions. This type of attentional training helps your mind focus on the present moment. And, if you are fully present in this moment, you are much less likely to get lost in thoughts about the past or worries about the future. Mindfulness-Based Stress Reduction helps you begin to turn off the automatic pilot and awaken to the fullness of your one and only life.

Register Now “I am an Army Veteran with PTSD. PTSD at its core is about being stuck in the past. MBSR training teaches you a proven methodology for being and staying in the present. For the first time in 20 years I am moving forward in my life and I credit this course for making that possible." Lisa https://youtu.be/8Is6K7bBd2Q Signup For Newsletter

item.title: In Person Stress Reduction Class
item.dc:creator: jbarkle1
item.content:encoded:
Mindfulness-Based Stress Reduction (MBSR) Class
Tuesday Nights September 20, 2022 - November 8, 2022 - 5:30pm-8:00pm
Required orientation September 13, 2022

This class is taught by a certified MBSR teacher and is the same course offered at hospitals, medical schools, colleges/universities and other institutions around the world. MBSR is the most researched evidence-based mindfulness program in the country. Over 40 years of research has shown statistically significant improvements in symptoms associated with certain illnesses, as well as, other physical and mental health. Participants in MBSR classes often report a greater sense of well-being and reduction in perceived stress. Classes are 2.5 hours in length and are held once a week for 8 weeks. Each class includes educational components, meditation, discussion and gentle movement. 

8 Week Stress Reduction Program 
Tuesday evenings September 20, 2022 - November 8, 2022 from 5:30pm - 8:00pm
Required Orientation on Tuesday, September 13, 2022 from 5:30pm-8:00pm
All Day Retreat on Saturday, Saturday, October 29, 2022 from 8:30am - 4:00pm

Since many participants who take MBSR have a pre-existing medical condition all participants are required to show proof of Covid-19 vaccination. Masking requirements will follow CDC guidelines. 

If you have any questions, feel free to contact mindfulalabama@gmail.com
​
Cost: $395 
Location: Crestwood Medical Center Women's Center, Huntsville, AL

Refund Policy: Refunds will be given, minus a $25 admin fee, if request is made in writing via email 2 weeks prior to class. No refunds will be given for cancellations less than 2 weeks prior to class.. If registrant does not provide notice prior to first class, neither refund nor credit toward future class will be given. Cancellation Policy: The Alabama Institute for Mindfulness, LLC reserves the right to cancel class due to low enrollment, prediction of severe weather events or other unforeseen circumstances. A full refund will be provided should the class be cancelled.​

Register Now

item.title: New Book Study Course
item.dc:creator: jbarkle1
item.content:encoded:
The Miracle of Mindfulness 
Led by Dr. Vanessa Miller-Curtis

Thursday, April 21 through Thursday, May 26, 2022
Time: 11:30am to 1:00pm (CST)

Thich Nhat Hanh said, “mindfulness is the capacity to be here, to witness deeply everything that happens in the present moment.” This course is about learning to apply mindfulness to our everyday lives through the teachings in The Miracle of Mindfulness. We will practice together, sit together, and reflect on and embrace the changes mindfulness can bring.

The class will meet every Thursday for 1.5 hours a week for 6 weeks. 

Cost $195.00
Book: The Miracle of Mindfulness by Thich Nhat Hanh
  -Participants purchase their own book
  -Electronic versions of this book may be available for free online

Vanessa Miller-Curtis, Ph.D. has over 12 years of experience in a variety of settings. Vanessa has spent several years developing and leading educational programs in the areas of Mindfulness, Shame and Guilt, and Contemplative Psychology in prison settings, outpatient clinics, and brain injury recovery and support groups. The effectiveness of therapeutic and educational programming for anyone on their overall well-being and its use as a tool to address anger, anxiety and other mental health issues is at the core of this work. Therapeutic educational programs pertain to psychological health and well-being. The importance of therapeutic and educational programming for any human being cannot adequately be expressed. For some, this may be the first opportunity to address a lifetime of maladaptive behaviors.

Register Now

item.title: Sunday Drop-in Community Meditation
item.dc:creator: jbarkle1
item.content:encoded:
Weekly Mindfulness Sessions Online
These are difficult times. So let's come together and practice some stress reduction and learn some adaptive coping skills. As counterintuitive as it may seem, paying attention to the thoughts, emotions and body sensations that are arising in these scary times may actually help us manage our stress. We can be blindsided by our fears when we constantly push them away. Mindfulness practice is about paying attention to the present moment, whether we like it or not. Mindfulness doesn't change the difficult times, it gives the deep roots we need to weather the storm.

Open To All:

Sunday Mindfulness Session 
Join us each Sunday of the month live via Zoom
Start your week with a 30 to 40 minute meditation practice and brief discussion. No experience is required and all are welcome. A session may include guided meditation practice, shared experience and a brief reading or poem.
Start time is 4:00pm (sign on at 3:55)

This event is free and open to the public.

Questions?

Contact mindfulalabama@gmail.com

Join Weekly Drop-In

item.title: Mindfulness-Based Stress Reduction(MBSR) Class - Tuesday Evenings Sept - Nov 2022
item.dc:creator: jbarkle1
item.content:encoded:
8 Week Stress Reduction Program
Tuesday evenings September 20,2022 - November 8, 2022 from 5:30pm - 8:00pm
Required Orientation on Tuesday, September 13, 2022 from 5:30pm-8:00pm
item.excerpt:encoded: Mindfulness-Based Stress Reduction (MBSR) is an eight-week intensive, psychoeducational program which was launched in 1979 at the University of Massachusetts Medical Center by Dr. Jon Kabat-Zinn. More than 20,000 people have completed this evidence-based program and learned to cultivate inner resources and develop skills that help them cope more effectively with stress, pain and illness. MBSR offers participants a powerful integrative approach, that when applied to everyday living can lead to health, healing and well-being. Mindfulness is about getting off "auto pilot," waking up and being fully present in the richness of each moment of life. Present moment awareness creates a space which helps us consciously respond to life  rather than reacting automatically from habit. The MBSR program utilizes meditation and mindful movement to to help individuals cultivate skills, increase awareness and access innate inner resources. Mindfulness helps us develop a deep inner reservoir accessible during the inevitable stressful events encountered in life.

item.title: Unwinding Anxiety
item.dc:creator: jbarkle1
item.content:encoded:
Unwinding Anxiety

A small group, app-based mindfulness training

A new, evidenced - based therapeutic intervention using a combination of a digital app on a cell phone or other device, in conjunction with weekly in-person meetings with a trained program facilitator/counselor offers 24/7 support on the spot, when you need it most.
This program, developed by Judson Brewer, MD PHD, Director of Research and Innovation at Brown University Center for Mindfulness School of Public Health is a ground- breaking, evidence-based method of habit change which engages the brain’s inherent, reward -based learning system. When anxiety strikes, triggering urges to react in ways that are unhealthy, whether it is to overeat, abuse substances, give in to anger or other impulses, we are usually feeling alone to battle the anxiety, overcome the urge and “white knuckle” the situation on our own.

With one on one guidance, as well as group support, we identify the triggers and behaviors and learn to short circuit the habit loop before anxiety takes over. In accordance with the latest neuroscience, change is not dependent on harsh self -discipline, but rather enlists the brain as an ally in moving toward behaviors that are intrinsically healthy and rewarding.

The Unwinding Anxiety program is a 90 minute weekly class in conjunction with the Unwinding Anxiety app which requires about 10 minutes a day. The Unwinding Anxiety website describes the app as "evidence based daily guidance designed for anyone suffering from anxiety." During the weekly classes participants will have an opportunity to further explore what they are learning about their anxiety triggers and anxiety habits. Participants will also have the opportunity in class to practice skills that help them break the cycle of worry and panic, as well as, cultivate "anti-anxiety tools".

 

More Info Register Now https://vimeo.com/240807523

item.title: Book Study
item.dc:creator: jbarkle1
item.content:encoded:
New Book Study Course

Led by Dr. Vanessa Miller-Curtis
Thursday, April 21 through Thursday, May 26, 2022
Time: 11:30am to 1:00pm (CST)

Thich Nhat Hanh said, “mindfulness is the capacity to be here, to witness deeply everything that happens in the present moment.” This course is about learning to apply mindfulness to our everyday lives through the teachings in The Miracle of Mindfulness. We will practice together, sit together, and reflect on and embrace the changes mindfulness can bring.

The class will meet every Thursday for 1.5 hours a week for 6 weeks.
Cost $195.00
Book: The Miracle of Mindfulness by Thich Nhat Hanh
-Participants purchase their own book
-Electronic versions of this book may be available for free online

Vanessa Miller-Curtis, Ph.D. has over 12 years of experience in a variety of settings. Vanessa has spent several years developing and leading educational programs in the areas of Mindfulness, Shame and Guilt, and Contemplative Psychology in prison settings, outpatient clinics, and brain injury recovery and support groups. The effectiveness of therapeutic and educational programming for anyone on their overall well-being and its use as a tool to address anger, anxiety and other mental health issues is at the core of this work. Therapeutic educational programs pertain to psychological health and well-being. The importance of therapeutic and educational programming for any human being cannot adequately be expressed. For some, this may be the first opportunity to address a lifetime of maladaptive behaviors.

Register Now

item.title: MSPE
item.dc:creator: jbarkle1
item.content:encoded:
Mindful Sports Performance Enhancement (MSPE)

This program, developed by Keith Kaufman, Carol Glass, and Timothy Pineau is an empirically based, six session mindfulness based mental training program developed for athletes. Mindful Sports Performance Enhancement is grounded in the traditions of Jon Kabat-Zinn’s  mindfulness-based stress reduction (MBSR) and Segal, Williams, and Teasdale’s mindfulness-based cognitive therapy (MBCT). Each session has experiential, educational, discussion, and home practice elements that teach athletes the basics of mindfulness. Once basic mindfulness exercises are introduced and practiced there is a gradual segue into sport-specific mindfulness exercises. While this program consists of six sessions that are 1.5 hours in length, it can be modified to accommodate the time constraints or needs of individual athletes, performers or athletic teams. 

Although the expression “the game is 90% mental” is frequently heard, “mental” training is seldom part of an athletes preparation. Athletes, as well as coaches, tend to focus on the physical, technical and tactical aspects of athletic performance and leave little or no time for what some have said is the most important aspect of any sports performance, the mental game. The quest for peak performance usually explores mental states like “flow” or being “in the zone”. In fact, the authors of Mindful Sports Performance Enhancement note, “perhaps most exciting are apparent links between MSPE training and the achievement of flow”. With MSPE, the cultivation of the mental game moves from being mostly a piecemeal approach to a systematic, empirically based program that builds on each athletes personal experience.

Mindful Sports Performance Enhancement (MSPE) may also be helpful for individuals in the performing arts. There are many similarities in the psychology of performance between athletes and musicians, dancers and actors. MSPE can be adapted and used with performing artists in all types of high pressure environments. The mindfulness skills learned in MSPE training can be woven not only into daily living but into the experience of being human and a musician, dancer, actor or athlete. The beauty of MSPE is that it has implications far beyond the athletic field or stage. It opens the door to a way of seeing more clearly even in the midst of a sometimes chaotic life. 

This program is facilitated by Leila Nabors, M.Ed., LPC, a certified Mindfulness-Based Stress Reduction teacher. Leila was a multi-sport competitive athlete in high school and college and enjoyed a 20 year teaching and coaching career. She has coached state championship high school teams and was the inaugural women’s volleyball coach at the University of Alabama in Huntsville. Leila left teaching and coaching to pursue a career in counseling and psychotherapy. Working with individual athletes and teams to help them reach their full potential, for Leila, is like returning home.

For more information or consultation regarding work with athletic programs, teams, individual athletes, or performing artists contact Leila Nabors directly at llnabors @comcast.net or 256-682-2235
